comments.text:
+Tamya Herbut I think people fail to see that this movie is categorized as 
historical fiction, and so is the novel this movie is based on by Thomas 
Keneally. This isn't supposed to be a documentary nor a docudrama, and it's 
people's fault that they believe that it's supposed to be a documentary. 
Oskar Schindler was real, and he did save thousands of lives. However, in 
Schindler's List, symbols such as the girl in the red coat were used 
because they obviously did not have accurate or detailed information to 
pass on, so they added things like this for the drama. Also, Amon Goeth was 
much worse in real life than he was in Schindler's List, so Speilberg had 
to tone him down because his actions were too violent to show on film. 
Schindler's List also simply can not be an accurate representation of the 
Holocaust. No movie can. The film is "far from reality" because it shows 
the lives of thousands being killed, while in reality, millions were 
killed. While Schindler's List is one of my favorite films, people need to 
realize that it is historical fiction.

comments.text:
+Tamya Herbut Ok, well I don't know why you felt compelled to post another 
comment about how the "drama soap" is inaccurate. I already commented on 
your other one, but I'll tell you again: (1). Schindler's List isn't 
supposed to be a documentary/docudrama, it's considered a historical 
fiction, and it's people's fault that they think it's supposed to be a 
documentary (2) Things like the ghetto liquidation did in fact happen, it's 
just that Speilberg and Keneally didn't have exact info about when 
Schindler was on the hill. Real historical info did not match what Keneally 
wrote in his novel, and why should it? It's historical fiction. However, 
Schindler did absolutely witness the liquidation of the ghetto. (3) Amon 
Goeth was much more ruthless and violent in real life than compared to the 
film/novel, so they toned him down. (4). Really nothing can be seen as an 
accurate representation of the Holocaust. Thousands died in Schindler's 
List, while millions died in reality.

comments.text:
Spielberg said the scene was intended to symbolise how members of the 
highest levels of government in the United States knew the Holocaust was 
occurring, yet did nothing to stop it. "It was as obvious as a little girl 
wearing a red coat, walking down the street, and yet nothing was done to 
bomb the German rail lines. Nothing was being done to slow down ... the 
annihilation of European Jewry," he said. "So that was my message in 
letting that scene be in color."[50] Andy Patrizio of IGN notes that the 
point at which Schindler sees the girl's dead body is the point at which he 
changes, no longer seeing "the ash and soot of burning corpses piling up on 
his car as just an annoyance."﻿
